message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the collecting ducts of the medulla suggests a diagnosis of medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts would only present as one or two cysts, while acquired polycystic kidney disease and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease would appear as cysts in the cortex and medulla, not specifically in the collecting ducts of the medulla.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the collecting ducts of the medulla with recurrent urinary tract infections suggests the most likely diagnosis is medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts are not associated with recurrent infections, while acquired and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney diseases affect the renal cortex or whole kidney, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the medulla of the kidney and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections suggest the diagnosis of medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts are usually solitary and less common than medullary sponge kidney. Acquired polycystic kidney disease is usually seen in patients with end-stage renal disease who have been on dialysis for a prolonged period of time. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease usually presents with symptoms later in life and is associated with a family history of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of multiple cysts of the collecting ducts in the medulla is most consistent with Medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts are usually small and found on the surface of the kidney. Acquired polycystic kidney disease is typically associated with prolonged dialysis and Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease would not be expected to present with recurrent UTIs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of cysts in the medulla suggests the most likely diagnosis is Medullary sponge kidney. Acquired polycystic kidney disease occurs in patients with chronic kidney disease and simple retention cysts are usually asymptomatic. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease affects the cortex, not the medulla.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of multiple cysts in the collecting ducts suggest the most likely diagnosis is Medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts are common but usually small, and acquired polycystic kidney disease is usually associated with long-term kidney disease. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease typically presents with multiple cysts throughout the entire kidney.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the medulla is a characteristic feature of Medullary Sponge Kidney. Simple retention cysts are usually found in the cortex and are asymptomatic. ADPKD and acquired polycystic kidney disease have cysts throughout the kidney, not just in the medulla. The history of recurrent UTIs may contribute to the formation of cysts in the medulla.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, history of recurrent urinary tract infections, and multiple cysts in the medulla suggest the most likely diagnosis is Medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts only affect the cortex, acquired polycystic kidney disease is typically associated with chronic renal failure, and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease causes cysts in both the cortex and medulla.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the medulla of the kidney suggests medullary sponge kidney, while autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease would have cysts in both medulla and cortex. Simple retention cysts are usually solitary and do not cause hematuria or flank pain, and acquired polycystic kidney disease is usually caused by chronic kidney disease or renal dialysis, which the patient does not have a history of.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple cysts in the medulla and recurrent urinary tract infections suggests medullary sponge kidney. Simple retention cysts typically do not cause hematuria or flank pain, acquired polycystic kidney disease is usually seen in patients with end-stage renal disease, and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease typically presents with cysts in the cortex and medulla.
